I was aware of the turbulence and, to put it kindly, the general lack of confidence in certain aspects of the CAA, and one did not have to be Einstein to work out that some action was needed. Therefore, it is with some pleasure that I see this amendment bill and am able to speak on this legislation today.

I fly almost weekly with large and small airlines and with charter operators. There is a very high standard of professionalism within that industry. I would hope that in the future when investigations are made—even a spot check of an aircraft—this standard is respected and we get a proper balance. Previous speakers have referred to the commonsense that is needed in all things. In that respect this industry is no different from any other. There have been times when some of the pilots have felt that some of the inspectors—whilst acknowledging the pilots' professionalism and sense of duty to the industry and to their passengers—were a little bureaucratic and a little petty, and could have performed their duties in a more practical way.

I refer to a few points within the schedule to the bill, such as the definitions of `accident', `serious incident', `incident', `safety deficiency' and `responsible person'. These are laid down in a very clear way. Let us hope that will assist in the operation of those activities. To hear that BASI, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, did not even have the right of entry without permission is quite remarkable when you think of what they are required to do, and the general locations of particularly serious accidents.

I welcome this bill. Although it is important that BASI be separate and independent, an integrated approach is equally important in the management of the increasing air traffic that will become more and more a feature of Australian life. It is essential that we have confidence in the safety of air travel throughout Australia. I am sure that this organisation will match that professionalism which already exists within the industry.

Our airways, if not the safest, are certainly equal to the safest airways in the world. It is essential for the travelling public and the industry that we do all within our power to retain that standard. As the previous speaker said, safe airways mean a profitable industry. The community expects that this legislation will regulate the air safety industry in a way which maximises that safety.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is very important in the light of recent events that have taken place in this country over the last three years with regard to the former Civil Aviation Authority. I refer to a couple of very tragic air disasters, and the inquiries that have taken place since then.

PARA.TAB: The intention of this bill is that aviation safety in Australia be enhanced by giving CASA, Airservices Australia and BASI clearly defined roles, functions and reporting responsibilities. The coalition supports the improvement of the situation.

There has been a great deal of concern expressed in recent times, over the last three or four years, over the ability of the couple of branches within the Civil Aviation Authority, as it was known, to deal with not only air traffic control but also the safety aspects of their brief as part of that larger GBE, the Civil Aviation Authority. As a result of a BASI inquiry into one of those serious accidents and a number of other parliamentary inquiries, the government saw fit to split the responsibilities of the former CAA into those two different bodies. Interestingly enough, I was involved in one of those inquiries, the one that was undertaken by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this parliament into the commercialisation process and the effects that that has had as far as the Commonwealth is concerned—not just the financial effects but also in this case the effects in implementing policy and providing safety measures for the travelling public.

The important part of the focus of that inquiry, the report from which I think was called Public business in the public interest, was on the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation. There was some very interesting evidence taken. Whilst we were doing that inquiry, the BASI inquiry started into the Monarch crash at Young. Off the back of that, another parliamentary committee started an inquiry into the safety regulation aspect and operations of the Civil Aviation Authority. Then, while that was all going on, we had the Seaview crash, or incident, where a number of people lost their lives. All that, put together, amounted to a great deal of pressure on the government. Ultimately, what happened was that the department was split up into the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia.

One of the things that really came out in the inquiry that we were conducting was that from time to time there was conflict of interest, as far as the CAA was concerned and as far as the minister responsible, the Minister for Transport was concerned, between the commercial imperatives and the safety imperatives. I will be the first to admit that the government has now recognised that, by establishing the Civil Aviation Safety Authority as a part of the department, the way I understand it, and Airservices Australia as the air traffic control or the commercial operation that remained as a GBE.

During the process of the inquiry it did occur quite clearly to us that, because of the conflict of interest, which involved the commercial imperatives of turning a profit and returning a dividend to the government as distinct from the safety factor as far as air safety control is concerned, there was an element of doubt about it. At the end of that whole inquiry we looked at a number of different models overseas. I know it was not part of the recommendations from the report that the Public Accounts Committee tabled in the parliament, but it is certainly a view that I firmly hold that we should look at dividing those responsibilities.

Where we have a government business enterprise, a commercial entity that is operating separately but where the Commonwealth is the individual shareholder, we should separate from the commercial aspect the responsibilities for the policy formulation, implementation and oversight that control and regulate the activity of that GBE. The portfolio minister who has control of that GBE as far as the policy and the regulation is concerned should not also be the shareholding minister on behalf of the Commonwealth, because there is always going to be a conflict of interest between trying to get as much money as possible back as revenue through that department from that GBE and the regulations that it is supposed to be enforcing.

As I said, I acknowledge the moves that the government made in this area. After some very tragic accidents that saw a number of Australian lives lost, we have seen the government move on the Civil Aviation Authority. A lot of the people that we were involved with and interviewed and who gave evidence before our inquiry are no longer there. I think the only high profile person who is still there is Captain Buck Brooksbank. A number of others have gone.

I acknowledge the fact that the government has split those responsibilities. Air traffic control is a commercial exercise, for sure. It is very important that the activities of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority be close to the responsible minister so that he can react, change regulations, change legislation, and ensure that the air travelling public in Australia are safe. This bill is probably taking a step down the path of clarifying the specific roles and activities, as circumstances arise, of BASI and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

The amendments to the bill ensure that the powers of investigation have a sound legislative base. They allow BASI to play an enhanced role by clearly defining its functions and ensuring that the organisation's investigations of aviation accidents and incidents conform to international civil aviation standards—and Australia is a signatory to the Convention on International Civil Aviation, which is loosely known as the Chicago convention. Thus the amendments enhance the very important role that BASI plays.

The amendments include definitions of accidents and incidents. Accidents occur when a person on board an aircraft dies or is seriously injured. An incident is a near accident or an event that adversely affects the safety of the aircraft. People working in the industry and the staff of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia would be required to report an accident or serious incident to BASI as soon as possible. The bill also provides some sanctions if that does not happen.

I am most interested in the part of the bill which relates to air safety in Australia. As a previous speaker mentioned, Australia probably has one of the best records in the world for air safety. We want to keep it that way. We want to maintain the credibility of our aviation industry. We must also bear in mind—and this is often being brought to the fore and was commented on by a previous speaker—the cost to the general aviation operators. Regular transport operators also have to be prepared to toe the line as far as the regulations are concerned. They have to be prepared to adhere to the regulations that are going to ensure air transport safety in Australia.

As I said at the start of my address, the opposition supports both amendments to this particular bill. Certainly, I am very keen to see this go ahead. It is travelling, as far as I am concerned, in the right direction, following on from, as I said, the findings of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. We recommended exactly what the government eventually undertook when it separated the functions of the old CAA into the areas where they are now. This bill is enhancing the powers of those organisations, particularly the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation group. It is very important.

The only thing now left for the government—or, God willing, the opposition when we get into government next year—to address is that very important element in the public policy area of commercialising and ultimately privatising a lot of the government business enterprises. It is important in the process on the way through to privatisation that the responsibilities of the portfolio minister and the shareholding minister in GBEs be split so there is no conflict of interest. The portfolio minister can then maintain a very close watch on the regulations and legislation involved in controlling that particular aspect of government activity.

However, it means that at the end of the day the government makes a decision—as the current government has on many occasions in recent months—to sell a number of different government business enterprises. The legislative oversight and regulations over these bodies that are being sold off into the private sector must be in place, first and foremost as far as I am concerned, to protect the community service obligations that we are used to have flowing from the Commonwealth in this nation. I flag that area for this government and certainly for the development of public policy in this area in the future. I agree with the recommendations in this bill, particularly with regard to aviation safety in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the coalition is supporting the amendments in the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 because air safety is of vital importance. As time goes by, it is going to become of increasing importance because more and more people are flying. Of course, as more and more people fly it means that there are more and more aircraft departures and landings and so the whole issue of air safety becomes more and more significant.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that BASI—the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation—has done such an excellent job; and nobody denies that. The references that are normally made, of course, are to the Monarch crash and the Seaview. There was also another one a little while before that with Oxley Airlines where three people lost their lives at Coffs Harbour during the airline strike. That emphasises the fact that the emphasis on air safety does not apply only to nuts and bolts; it should also apply to people. I would just like to make the point in this debate that, if we are going to have regulations to provide for air safety, there should perhaps be a stricter monitoring of what is happening with the individuals, the human beings, who are involved in flying aircraft.

The CAA, as the shadow minister for transport, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) said, had fallen into great disrepute; there is no doubt about that. It has been split into two—Airservices Australia, which is more or less the commercial arm of it with services for air navigation and so on, and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. There has been quite a deal of concern within the general aviation area, and my friend and colleague the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) mentioned that just a moment ago. But there does seem to be a feeling in the general aviation area that they are being subjected to a degree of injustice.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe), when delivering the second reading speech, made reference to the measures being `budget funded'. Of course, they are budget funded, but the question has to be asked, `Where is the money coming from?' That is a very salient and very valid question. It would appear that the money is coming from the fuel excise levy on avgas and again it does appear that there is a degree of injustice there.

I know that the parliamentary secretary has made it quite clear, in terms of a general claim that general aviation is subsidising the regular passenger flights, that this is not the case. But there are areas where, I believe, this is the case. For instance, general aviation will be subsidising the RPT sector in some places. An example is a nine-seat Chieftain aircraft operating from Orange, New South Wales, to Sydney. A private aircraft with only the pilot on board will pay the same amount for safety regulation as a Chieftain operated by an airline such as Hazelton over the same route with eight paying passengers. This, in terms of the people involved in general aviation, is an example of how general aviation is subsidising some sectors of the RPT sector.

The point has to be made, too, that while at one stage the avgas levy did decrease, the general aviation sector had to accept a substantial reduction in services to reduce that as well. That should not be forgotten. It is interesting, too, that the CAA recorded a net profit before interest and tax of $96 million in 1993-94 and, of course, at that time it wanted to increase the levy. It is fascinating that on 1 June this year the acting chief executive officer of the CAA, Buck Brooksbank, admitted before the Senate estimates committee that 60 per cent of the proposed rise was to increase the government's return from the CAA. So 60 per cent of the increase going forward in the levy was purely to give the government some more profit at the expense, in particular, of the general aviation sector—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a conflict of interest.

—It is totally unsatisfactory—and, indeed, a conflict of interest. But there is some good news. I am pleased to tell the Committee that, as from last night, aviation gasoline will be almost a cent cheaper because of a coalition amendment which was passed by the Senate. Aviation gasoline, or avgas, as we know it, is the fuel that is used in most propeller aircraft, and in the 1995-96 budget the government increased the duty on the fuel by 1.847c per litre to a total of 19.08c a litre. That duty also increased by an additional three per cent on 1 August as a result of the CPI indexation process. That is just one more example of the government increasing taxation by stealth.

PARA.TAB: Of the 1.847c per litre increase, 0.964c was used to increase the funding of Airservices Australia, the organisation responsible for providing airways services such as air traffic control. As we have already learnt from the CEO when he was before the Senate estimates committee in June, a great deal of that is going just to provide extra profits for the government, which is totally inappropriate. The coalition believes that funding air traffic control services through a fuel duty alone is totally inequitable.

It is not appropriate that fuel duties should be the only way of providing the costs of the air traffic control service. The reason is that many general aviation operators and private pilots rarely use air traffic services because they do not fly in controlled air space. It is totally unfair that they are still required to pay thousands of dollars a year in duty. For example, agricultural operators currently pay Airservices Australia an average of $7,800 per plane per year for airways services they do not use. Again, that is totally inappropriate.

The 1.847c a litre increase in the duty applied from 1 July 1995 and I am pleased to tell the Committee that Senator Warwick Parer moved amendments in the Senate to two government bills to scale back that duty increase to 0.883c per litre. That is the same as the increase in the duty on the fuel used in jet aircraft and is needed to help fund safety regulations.

We know the need for funding safety regulation, but one can only be boggled at the injustice of suggesting that propeller driven aircraft using avgas should have to pay more in fuel duty than jets. I am very pleased indeed that that has been changed. I only hope when the Senate amendment comes back later in the week, or perhaps even later today, that the House of Representatives will be sensible about it and accept that amendment.

There is another point which I think is of significance, particularly when we are looking at the question of increasing the cost of aviation through the increase of fuel levies. Even though we are intending to improve air safety, we want to be very certain that we do not make it so expensive to run aircraft that people are encouraged to take some short cuts.

I have had some contact with some aircraft maintenance people and they make the point that, from a maintenance point of view, any increase in fees for maintenance people will compromise safety in smaller aircraft operations. The cost of a proper aircraft bolt may be $10. Heaven forbid if, because of the costs involved, somebody might be forced to cut corners and get one at 10c from the local hardware store. That is a recipe for disaster.

The point should be made that making the aircraft maintenance industry more expensive can only compromise safety further. Disasters such as the Monarch Airlines incident at Young and, more recently, the Seaview air disaster off the New South Wales north coast will become more common and a greater loss of life may result. Aircraft owners and operators may be more likely to fail to record all hours flown—and I hope they do not—and omit to report defects and unserviceabilities on their aircraft. This could be exacerbated if there is some attempt to increase costs on maintenance.

There must be full communication between aircraft engineers, pilots and owner-operators. Otherwise many faults that exist in aircraft may go unnoticed. It should be noted that, even during regular maintenance, some unserviceabilities or faults may not be found because they only appear when the aircraft is in operational mode and they are not detectable during routine maintenance. There needs to be a greater increase in communication at all levels of the aviation industry. Finally, as I said before, the coalition supports the amendments. They are in the interests of air safety and that is certainly something that we should all support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Bevis)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Consideration resumed from 22 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes amendments to a number of Commonwealth acts as a consequence of the enactment of the Family Law Reform Act 1995. The Family Law Reform Act 1995 makes substantial changes to the Family Law Act 1975. The act provides encouragement to parents to reach agreement themselves or with the assistance of a counsellor or mediator, rather than resorting to litigation to resolve their differences. In particular, it repeals and substitutes part VII which establishes the relationships between children and their parents. The reform act as a whole seeks to change the approach taken by parents towards their children and emphasises the concept of parental responsibility for the care, welfare and development of their children, rather than the current concepts of guardianship, custody and access which are typified by notions of ownership of children.

PARA.TAB: A number of acts administered by other portfolios have as their foundation, or as a part of their foundation, the outmoded concepts of guardianship, custody and access which need to be replaced. The Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995 gives effect to these changes in the terminology in other Commonwealth legislation. The bill will bring other Commonwealth legislation into line with the reforms and facilitate the operation of the associated legislation applying the new concepts.
The bill also amends the Evidence Act 1995, to apply that act to appeals to the Family Court from a decision of a court of summary jurisdiction. These appeals are heard de novo by the Family Court.

The bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. The bill is not controversial. With the exception of the minor amendment to the application of the Evidence Act, the bill is not intended to affect the operation or application of other Commonwealth legislation. It simply serves to replace outdated terminology such as `guardianship', `custody' and `access'.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the bill. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) has outlined, is a consequential bill effecting amendments to legislation in the area of citizenship, child support, child care, migration, passports and social security. It was only last week that we were dealing with the Family Law Reform Bill, which has now been enacted, as the parliamentary secretary outlined in his second reading speech.

PARA.TAB: On that occasion, we took the opportunity of recalling the involvement of the Senate committee in reviewing the legislation—the outcome, in relation to the reform package, of a good deal of discussion on amendments that were proposed, some of which were accepted by the government, some of which were not and some proposed by the government and third parties which also led to changes. Finally, the bill was considered before the House of Representatives when all of the amendments that had been effected by the Senate were accepted.

This bill should have been debated properly when we dealt with the reform package. It was appropriate that it be dealt with in a cognate situation. I was almost inclined to approve this bill at the first reading stage to get it out of the way. That may have been a problem because I notice that a long list of speakers has been proposed to debate this bill, although this seems to be diminishing.

I do not intend to detain the Committee, much to the surprise of some of my colleagues, other than to say that we will not be opposing the measure. I could reiterate my comments in relation to the select committee which dealt with the Family Law Act and to the better utilisation of committees of the House of Representatives. They are comments worthy of reiterating, but they stand on the record and I do not intend to detain the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Others have done likewise.

—Yes, and I recall them very favourably and hope that, if we resume and if we consider further amendments to the Family Law Act during this session, we might be able to give that sort of consideration to them. I suspect that it will be up to another government to better utilise the services of the House of Representatives.
—Another parliament.

—It will be up to another government to utilise better the committees of this chamber and the joint parliamentary committees. I encourage those who have consideration of these matters to recognise that skills in relation to these forensic matters do not necessarily reside only in the Senate; they reside in this chamber as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The address by the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) on the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995 is there for the record. I was surprised by the few minutes that his address took because normally, in the main chamber, the debate goes on longer when he is involved. I am very pleased to talk in support of the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995 because I believe that this House, in its short history, has seen its fair share of flaring tempers and rising passions. Members of this parliament have always entertained very strong opinions on every subject and voiced them with great conviction—as they should. Rarely has an issue caused as much interest and heard opinions voiced as much as family law—or, indeed, family law reform.

PARA.TAB: While the different sides of this House disagree on the ways and the means that governments should approach or relate to families, I am sure I will hear no arguments or interjections when I say that only by supporting families in this country, by making them strong and secure, will we keep the social health of our nation as robust as it is presently.

The family nurtures the individual in childhood, supports it in later life and, throughout, offers love, contact and a sense of belonging. Of course, when I say the word `family', I define the term broadly. Gone are the days when our interpretation of the word `family' consisted solely of mum, dad and however many children. It is not that this sort of family no longer exists but, in our communities today, the number of different shapes and forms families take are almost breathtaking—but still, each unit offers the same benefits.

Any bill, however remotely involved with Australian families, parents and their responsibilities to their children, deserves our thorough attention. In tampering with or developing any piece of legislation concerning the family, we are laying our hands on the fibres that hold us together and, as such, we should treat the debate with great seriousness and heavy consideration.

Before I turn my attention to the consequential amendments bill before this Main Committee, I wish to begin by touching on the recent and past history concerning family law reform in this country, and then continue by discussing the importance this government places on making sure that any legislation it supports concerning the family is absolutely foolproof.

The 1994 Family Law Reform Bill, passed by this House last November, represents an attempt by our present Labor government to continue the groundbreaking reform begun in 1975 when the Whitlam government passed the country's first Family Law Act. I know that in recent weeks we have once again enjoyed a thorough appraisal of the Whitlam government, from commentators of many different political persuasions, so I will not dwell at length on its achievements.

However, I will say that, with the 1975 Family Law Act, Australian families and our legal fraternity had for the first time a government that was committed to changing family law, committed to improvement and committed to providing a legal framework that made the problems associated with family breakdown easier to bear. Nevertheless, despite the advances that we have made since 1975, family law has remained the extremely volatile area we always knew it to be. This is not a surprise, I believe, to any of us. It would have been unrealistic for us all to assume that we could solve these problems with one fell swoop of the legislative pen.
When my colleague the Attorney-General, the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Lavarch)—the honourable member for Fisher, as he was—spoke in the House on this topic some three years ago, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with something which in a certain body of cases simply cannot be resolved.

And of course he is right. Unfortunately, sometimes conflict upon the breakdown of families and marriages is inevitable. The best family law system in the world—and that is what we, I believe, as a government, are endeavouring to provide—could not make this fact any different.

PARA.TAB: Those people that blame the present Family Law Act for their pains or their frustrations will always cry foul—as can be expected. We are talking about people at one of the lowest points in their lives. Of course they are going to blame family law or the government—or anything else that makes an easy target for them, for that matter.

I have always been thankful for the stable family environment in which I grew up, and I have been proud of the fact that my husband and I were able to provide the same stability and loving atmosphere for our children. Yet I would have to have been living in a ivory tower all of those years not to have had some experience with friends and loved ones undergoing the heartbreaking twin turmoils of divorce and the painful decisions regarding care of and contact with children.

My colleague the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) put it quite eloquently when debating the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 in the House in November last year. Saying that he was `stunned and appalled', he asked:

SPEECH.PARA: How is it possible for a man to have sired a child and for a woman to have borne that child and then feel about each other the way they do and express sentiments of venom and hatred, often verging on violence—certainly oral violence?

These are the emotions we are dealing with—irrational anger and unexplainable bitterness. Yet perhaps the most sobering thought is that the people embroiled in such torment are exactly the same as you and I—another case of `There, but for the grace of God, go I'.

PARA.TAB: Yet it could also be unfair to say that for someone to criticise the present act simply meant that they were emotionally unstable or unhinged due to recent experiences. The present act, despite its groundbreaking character, is not perfect, even though the joint select committee's review of the Family Law Act, tabled in the parliament in late 1992, reported it was an effective tool in administering Australian family law matters.

Nevertheless, the same committee made 120 separate recommendations for improvement. Committed as the government is to families in this country, we have been determined to follow that through. While it would have been easy for this government to use the excuse `People will always complain. Therefore we don't have to do anything about it,' it would have been reneging on our responsibilities to the Australian people. This Labor government has never been about taking the soft option or the easy way out. That is why we are back again now, 20 years later, to carry forward once again the same ideals of change and improvement cultivated by the Whitlam government

I think it is a given when I say that more Australians will, unfortunately, come into contact with family law than any other legal field. Family law is one of the most constant subjects raised in my electorate office by constituents aggrieved at their circumstances and at the supposed unfairness of the system. The situation, I imagine, is the same for most of my colleagues.

The 1994 bill aimed to enshrine in the law a right to adequate and proper parenting for children, to assure their care and welfare and to help them achieve their full potential. This included the right to know and be cared for by both parents, as well as a right of contact with other people significant to their care, their welfare and development, such as grandparents and extended family.

The consequential amendments bill is a further link in the chain of this government's plan to make sure that our children and their families get the best possible deal from the laws surrounding their relationship. This consequential amendments bill broadens the foundation laid by the 1994 Family Law Reform Bill. In particular, it concerns itself with part VII of the original bill which seeks to modify the language associated with parental responsibility concerning their children. The passing of the consequential amendments bill will carry these new definitions through to other acts where the terminology relating to the relationship between parent and child is also important.

One of the main thrusts of the 1994 bill was that it sought to rid the language describing the parent-child relationship of its negative connotations of ownership and title, and substitute it with a new sense of meaning. `Custodian' and `guardian', used by many of us when discussing criminals and imprisonment, becomes `carer.' `Access,' a word commonly used by landowners and in questions of property, was replaced in the bill by the word `contact.'

The modification in language is a direct flow-on from the bill's redefinition of parental responsibility. A parent is not an owner of a child, as is suggested by the word `custodian'. A child is not the chattel of a parent. Of course, we all know that a parent does not enjoy the right to do with the child whatever he or she wants, as they would with a new car or a house, but that is how the present definitions can be interpreted as describing their relationship—especially by parents feeling betrayed by their spouses or by the courts.

It is an unfortunate observation to make but during family breakdowns parents sometimes treat their children as such, and it is not surprising when the language reinforces these ideas. One parent is the winner, gaining custody, and the other is the loser, with only access. Is not our terminology helping to compound the misery these parents are feeling? Where does the child's welfare stand in all of this? Over the last 20 years, it has been a continuing theme in any literature on child abuse or the child-parent relationship that the words we say to a child can determine how they feel about themselves. Children's feelings of self-worth and their perceptions of themselves develop from what they hear people—and in particular their parents—say about them If you call a child an idiot long enough, they will start to believe it. If you call a child worthless long enough, they will start to believe it. If you say to a child, `I am your custodian', with all of its negative connotations of ownership, then surely there is a chance that they will start to feel that way—owned, an object.

Language is a living, breathing thing. Just as the relationship between parent and child has changed over the last 20 years, so too does the terminology we use to explain that relationship have to change. If we are seeking to deliver a clearer definition of what it means to be a parent, surely we have to restructure its associated terms. Language, as we would all know from our experiences in this committee and in the House, is a powerful and often brutal force. Day in and day out words are flung across the chambers, and we all know that, for all of our many years of experience of political name calling, sometimes words can wound, they can elicit pain and anger.

Language is powerful and no-one can doubt that. With this in mind, how can we then turn around to our children, to Australian parents, knowing what we know from our own experiences, and say to them, `Well, with regard to the language used to describe your relationship, never mind how it makes you feel; we know what it really means, don't we?' The fact is, we do not. There is too much room for a child and a parent to draw negative connotations. We have to remember that words, language, can scar. We have a duty, as the representatives of ordinary Australian men and women, to see that the language covering as potentially explosive an issue as the parent-child relationship is given as little scope as possible to be misinterpreted throughout our society, and not just in family law. Our terminology must be simple, unbiased, and anti-inflammatory.

As I have already stated, the government seeks to firmly establish a new notion of parental responsibility where the care, welfare and development of a child is paramount—an obligation shared by both sets of parents with no winners and losers involved. Marriage entered into by two responsible people is an equal partnership. Their role as parents is also based on that same notion of equality. While a marriage break-up means that a partnership is dissolved, it does not mean that the parents can now abdicate their equal and continuing responsibilities to their child. The language of the law has to reflect this as well.

The change in definition and usage outlined in the 1994 bill and in the current consequential amendments bill should not be seen as some sort of exercise in politically correct window dressing. This is not about calling a bald man anything but bald. It is an attempt, supported by the Family Law Council, to rid the language used in family law of its negative and adversarial elements when it comes to parents and their children. It should not be seen as an attempt by this Labor government to undermine a parent's role in nurturing, rearing or bringing up their child. It is exactly the opposite: we hope to make the relationship better by fostering in our community a renewed respect of parenting and what it means to be a parent.

Critics affirm that there is no proof that changing the definition of parental responsibility and redefining the language associated with it will lead to parents becoming less adversarial in their battles over their children. Those same critics say that parents are normally possessive of their children, that they will always be so and no modification in language is going to change that. Those critics are exactly right. The feuding parents of children will often succumb to possessive emotions, bathing themselves in recrimination and hate at the unintentional expense of their child.

When the joint select subcommittee conducted its review of the Family Law Act, Mr Justice Joske, in a submission to that committee, criticised the changes. His Honour stated that because the words `custody' and `access' are still used in the widespread community, confusion would result about what the new terms actually meant. With all due respect to His Honour's experience and his legal knowledge, while I agree that it will not be easy changing our community's understanding of new terms such as `contact' and `carer' instead of `access' and `custodian' and that these words have become entrenched in our understanding of family law, I would suggest that with them, too, have become entrenched the negative concepts those words convey.

I think the value for our community in introducing these new terms far outweighs any confusion that might eventuate. The benefits are too great. In fact, I believe the confusion is already prevalent when it comes to the old terms used to define parental roles in family law. I am reminded of an excellent example that my colleague the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) used during the debate over the Family Law Reform Bill when it was first introduced to this House in November last year.

He stated that the concept of joint guardianship is not clearly understood in the community. He went on to say that, as often happens in family law matters, one party is given custody of the child but both parents are given joint guardianship. Now, because of the win/lose connotations of the word `custody', the party who only gains joint guardianship feels like a loser. What is that worth when they do not get `custody'—`control'—of the child's welfare, education, et cetera?

However unfortunate it is for a parent to view a child as a possession, we must face the fact that a child is often seen as such when it comes to these matters. The change in terminology covered by the Family Law Reform Bill and continued by this consequential amendments bill will go some way towards alleviating these bitter feelings. As I stated before, they will not end them, but at least it will be a start. The Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995 is a start in producing a change in understanding in our community.

While not attempting to belittle the emotional torment these parents must be going through, or, indeed, their genuine desire to do what they think is best for their children, is it not right that we take steps towards reducing the hostility and the venom associated with these exchanges and reduce the opportunities for such antagonism to be expressed? It is because family breakdown evokes such basic emotions and involve such strong feelings that we need these changes. This is where the benefits of change in terminology lie.

The consequential amendments bill is all about starting to advance these benefits throughout the rest of our society, starting with a handful of important acts. Of course, the Family Law Act is not the only area where the definition of parenthood and the status of children is important. As we know and can imagine, changes of terminology concerning a relationship central to human relations is going to affect a considerable amount of legislation.

The bill will amend the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1988, the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988, the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Migration Act 1958, the Passports Act 1938 and the Social Security Act 1991. These are all pieces of legislation that are central to our community and to how our society is run.

We must continue the process started by the Family Law Reform Bill last year—at the very least to avoid the confusion mentioned by Mr Justice Joske. We must bring these pieces of legislation into line with the reforms proposed by the Family Law Reform Bill. When the Family Law Reform Bill is passed it would be irresponsible for us to have one piece of legislation saying one thing, and a whole lot of other acts saying another. We need to provide uniformity and, most importantly, to send a very clear message to the Australian people. Politicians have always been famous for talking about the needs of families and their desire to see families get a fair deal. Lip-service and kissing babies can only go so far.

This bill deserves the support that it has received from both sides of the House. It offers families a fair deal. More, it lengthens the helping hand offered by the government to estranged families. It is a small helping hand that may assist parents in forging a new start with each other, and most particularly with their children. I do not think any of us could object to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), used a phrase `there but for the grace of God' in the context of involvement with the Family Court. I have actually been involved as a user of the system. I speak not only from the point of view of a member of parliament—who, like so many of my colleagues, finds that this is one of the areas where I am consulted most frequently by constituents—but as one who has had direct user involvement.

PARA.TAB: Apart from the natural difficulties and the pain that are associated with marriage breakdown and the consequential action, my experience was that the process itself—the court, the law and associated procedures—added several layers of difficulty to what was already a difficult time. Obviously, my view is very much coloured by some of that personal experience.

We all share the concerns that the previous speaker mentioned in terms of the desirability of successful families. But that is not always the case. The figures show that at the turn of the century approximately 40 per cent of families are going to be divorced. We are talking about a very substantial proportion of the population.

As the previous speaker on this side, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), has already said, the coalition supports the amendments. But we are dealing with people, and the thing that worries me in this legislation and associated legislation is that all too often the sensitivity of dealing with the people on the ground is fundamentally not there.

The Price committee—and the member for Chifley (Mr Price) is here—came up with a very comprehensive report. I would like to see more action from the government on many of his recommendations. His report dealt with a lot more of the practical realities of the world that people find themselves in when involved with the Family Court.

When we talk about the 1994 bill, and both parents being involved in bringing up the child, the modification of language and all of the high-flown phrases that the parliamentary secretary has just alluded to, it seems to me that is not adequate. You can have all the language you like. You can come up with phrases that are meant to be less negative, less threatening and all the rest of it. But when people are in strife—whether they are at war with each other or not at war with each other—when they are trying to resolve the future and fate of their children, you need to deal with the individuals sensitively.

The fundamental problem with the present system is, frankly, that that does not happen. You are dealt with as a number. The delays in the process—whether it is mediation, whether it is counselling, whether it is formal legal action—go on interminably. If you go along to mediation, you do not get the same mediator from one session to the next. There is no ability to get a mediator to give any constructive help or report what has been said—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're actually talking about counselling.

—I am talking about counselling. It seems to me that, unless we address those on the ground issues of how we deal with people, all the rest of it, frankly, is of little consequence. I think that is where a lot of this legislation falls down. I do not dispute the good intent, but what I am saying is that it is not practical in real terms.

PARA.TAB: A comment was made about Judge Joske. I actually had some first-hand experience with Judge Joske and I would have to say he was undoubtedly one of the shining lights in the family law process, in my experience.

I am not going to go through the details of the bill. As the parliamentary secretary said, we are aiming to amend, as a consequence of previous legislation, a number of other acts. Of course, we have also seen the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 reviewed by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, and it raised a number of concerns. It talked about its concerns about inequality of bargaining power; it talked about the need to look at alternative action in terms of conciliation, mediation or court proceedings; it talked about the problem of immunity of mediators and the need to have some standards if you are going to give immunity; and it talked about perhaps having some variations or exemptions in terms of the rights of the children and their best interests. I think those are all very practical, legitimate concerns. Although the government in its response has come back and said, `We accept these,' I have not seen any actual action from the government in dealing with those.

So I have a number of concerns. I think those concerns start with the Chief Justice of the Family Court. It seems to me he is far too keen to jump into publicity and get into empire building. I recently heard him talking about wanting to extend his activities into Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander activities and so on and so forth. It seems to me that his job should be to make sure that the empire that he has already got is running effectively, and that is not happening at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I was to make those comments, you'd be criticising me for interfering with the independence of the judiciary.

—I am saying that, if he wants to get up and engage in the public debate, he must expect people to respond to him. What I am saying is that, until he is running his courts and his system in an efficient, effective manner, he should not be looking to extend the remit of the area in which he functions.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk about children and their rights, very briefly. The point that it seems to me we have come to in this country is that we are giving children rights and representation at a time often well before they are of a maturity to understand and to deal in those situations. In a divorce case, a 12-year-old or a 13-year-old might well have separate representation, but it seems to me they have no ability to tell the separate representative in any meaningful way what to do. I have known cases where the separate representation has just not been carried through, where the representative has changed from one month to the next month, where there was one brief meeting and the child did not even know what he was being asked to make a decision about as to which parent he wanted to live with, and things of that sort. The system is fundamentally not administered with a consideration for the people who are being affected by it.

The Child Support Agency, as we all know, is an absolute disaster. That is another area that the government could pay a lot of attention to. The quality of the counselling is something that needs to be given a lot more practical attention to. Lawyers do not know what to advise clients. They say, `It depends which judge you draw in the morning as to which way it is going to go.' How the hell can you deal with a situation like that? If it depends on the luck of which judge you get, how can a lawyer give you quality advice?
The other thing that I am really concerned about with the legislation is where you get an imbalance in the power of the partners. That seems to me the biggest flaw in the whole system.

Whilst obviously the government and the opposition both support this legislation, I have to flag that I have some concerns. Words will not change the reality. I think there is much more of a need for a practical approach to implementing legislation in this whole area, and, whilst I support the bill, I have to say that I do so with great trepidation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 2.30 p.m. to 5.33 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful for my audience arriving, without which this speech would be dispensable. This afternoon we are considering, I think, two very important bills. One of the principles behind them is that we should get away from talking in family breakdown situations about custody and access. I totally and wholeheartedly approve of that—after all, it is eons since we started, in this country, treating women as property or as being owned by their husbands. The terms `custody' and `access' unfortunately do treat children as though they are a prized possession. In lieu of that, we talk about residency and contact. I would urge all members of this parliament to embrace this change of terminology.

PARA.TAB: The other thing that is part and parcel of the bill is the parenting plans. I do not want to equivocate about this but I have to say that, even though I totally support the concept of parenting plans, they are unlikely to make one iota of difference in terms of trying to resolve bitter disputes that often erupt at the end of relationships and marriages.

These parenting plans are going to benefit people who really do not need to benefit from parenting plans. Having said that, I am unequivocally in support of them. This is real progress and, again, I would urge all members of this House to fully support it. I should have mentioned that this basically arose through the work of the joint committee that was chaired by Jim McKiernan. I would like to pay tribute to Senator McKiernan and his committee in the previous parliament, because they were the icebreakers in family law.

The committee's first report was very important, and a lot of the amendments in these bills reflect the recommendations of the good work of that committee. I am also pleased to confess modestly that, as chairman in this parliament, I was able to bring down a report on the Child Support Agency. It is a matter of regret to me that the government has picked up only 53 of the 163 recommendations and is still considering the toughest 110. I wish it well in its deliberations. That report will stand the test of time.

I have to apologise, when I speak on this bill, to many hundreds of ordinary Australians because, during the course of that inquiry, as chairman, I suggested that I and the committee were fully aware of the real difficulty that exists in terms of what we call now residency and access. I suggested that the committee would be taking up the problem in its other inquiry into funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia. Frankly, we have failed to do that. I do have a genuine sense of letting a lot of people down. Those problems will not go away and they are not going to be rectified by the change of terminology—as welcome as that change is—or by proposing parenting plans—as welcome as that innovation is.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may be aware that I drew the ire of the Chief Justice of the Family Court for a speech I made on 1 May 1995. I suppose I will always say about myself in this House that I am a radical, and the standard definition of a `radical' is someone who is prepared to fight for their beliefs. I guess you will understand better than most that, coming from the western suburbs of Sydney, I would rejoice in the proposition that I am a radical. I thought the speech I made was eminently reasonable because I pointed out that there were a lot of difficulties with the Family Court and the family law area. I had the temerity to suggest that it was not working.

I do not want to regurgitate that speech, but I pointed out that we were spending over $100 million per year of government money to the Family Court in the terminal stages of relationships and marriages: that is, when they were dead and over, we would spend the money, but not up-front. This did not make good sense to me, and I raised issues of access and equity. I suggested that legal rights which you are financially incapable of exercising are not rights at all. Go around and talk to people who are embroiled in family law matters and ask them about the absolutely extraordinary amounts of money that they are paying. We cannot even afford to fund cases of merit for women and their children who are financially eligible. Legal aid is running out.

I raised access and equity issues. I also had the temerity to say that the Family Court locks people into a formalistic litigation pathway. That is the truth of the matter. I suggested that we needed to make a fresh start in family law. Heaven forbid, I praised the honourable member for Menzies, Mr Andrews, a member of the committee, because Kevin, amongst other people, has been pre-eminent in saying that we ought to have pre-marriage counselling, pre-relationship counselling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prevention is better than cure.
—Absolutely. We ought to be spending money up front in the relationship if we are serious about families and serious about relationships.

PARA.TAB: For my sins, the Chief Justice launched an extraordinary attack on me. He suggested that he had no confidence in working with me as chairman of the committee. I regret that I need to read this because I cannot get it incorporated but I will. I responded:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Justice Nicholson, has written what appears to be an extraordinary letter about me to the Prime Minister expressing no confidence in me as Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Matters.
I had not seen the letter and I was only aware of the letter from reading what the Chief Justice has selectively chosen to leak to a national newspaper.
I have only today been faxed a copy of the letter.

The Chief Justice appears to have chosen to skate across dangerous constitutional ice. Some may see his actions as intimidatory, which of course if it interfered in the discharge of my duties, might constitute a breach of parliamentary privilege.
In writing to the Prime Minister, he displays a lack of understanding of parliamentary procedure and perhaps separation of powers.

I am surprised that the Chief Justice has chosen to attack me personally, my character and reputation. I have launched no such personal attack against him or his office. The Chief Justice's action appears to me to be unseemly and inconsistent with the high office he holds.
What appears to have caused the Chief Justice to take such umbrage has been the fact that I have put some of my ideas in the market place of public opinion.
This process often occurs in a democracy. Others might suggest it is an indispensable feature of a modern democracy.
I have an unshakeable belief that ordinary citizens have a right to be informed and a right to form their own views rather than having things imposed on them from on high.
Indeed the public's views are often translated into government policy, this can be facilitated by the parliamentary committee system.
The public have given me their overwhelming support for my ideas and I am grateful for that support.

I understand that the Chief Justice has suggested that I am indulging in "idiosyncratic personal aggrandisement". I reject the accusation but I am bemused that the accusation should come from someone with such a propensity for media headlines.

Far from declining the Chief Justice the opportunity to appear before the committee, the Committee has had to postpone hearing the Chief Justice because he has chosen to go overseas for six weeks. The Committee will be calling the Chief Executive Officer of the Family Court on 15 June.

I am prepared to call an extraordinary meeting of the Committee earlier at the convenience of the Chief Justice if he wishes to interrupt his six week trip. Otherwise the Committee will hear the Chief Justice on his return.
Therefore the accusation that the committee or I am unwilling to hear the Chief Justice does not appear to be consistent with the facts.
I have previously met informally with the Chief Justice and also with his brother judges. I am more than willing to do so again to constructively engage in a dialogue about improving family law.
The Chief Justice has apparently accused me of bias.
I can happily reassure the Chief Justice on a number of points.
Firstly, I am biased towards ordinary people and ensuring that they get a fair go, I actually think that's my job.
Secondly, I am always open to facts and ideas.
Thirdly, the Committee will rigorously assess the evidence placed before it, without fear or favour and its final report will, I believe, follow the high standards of its two earlier reports.
Lastly, I would offer some free advice. The Chief Justice might examine and reflect on the evidence placed before the Committee by Terry O'Donahue.
Perhaps it is the Chief Justice who needs to "reconsider his position"?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—I remind the honourable member for Chifley that it is against standing orders to reflect offensively against a member of the judiciary. You have not done that to date. I mention it in case it is coming in future remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's his right of reply.
—I do not need help from the member for Fisher.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to point out that today in the Senate and in the House a most damning report into the funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia has been tabled. I do not know how I can say what I wish to say, other than to point out that, if this were a statutory authority or a department, more than serious questions would be asked. We would not be satisfied with the status quo.
—The only comment I make concerns the use of offensive words.
—Sure.
—You have not done that to date.

—And I have no wish to. What I need to do, if I have been guilty of anything during my chairmanship of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues and now as a committee member, is to say it is legitimate for ordinary people to speak up about their concerns about family law. Just because it is traumatic and emotional, it does not mean that we cannot embark on a reform process to make things better. The Chief Executive Officer of the Family Court publicly says, `We can't do any better. This is an impossible situation.' There are one or two apologists in the parliament who, equally, say these things.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, I have the temerity to stand before you and my peers and say that, no matter how traumatic or emotional, we have to do better. This is a case of the emperor's new clothes. We cannot all run around and say that everything is perfect and wonderful when we know it is not.

Let me give you an example. The Family Court has always had the responsibility to provide counselling for people when their relationships and marriages are in strife, not before they are dead—what one might call proactive counselling. They have never ever done proactive counselling and all the while they have screamed about a lack of money. The truth of the matter is, looking at the report, that they have had heaps of money. Not only have they had heaps of money, but they have borrowed against future money. They have ticked it up on their Bankcard.

If it had not been for the Justice Statement this year, the Family Court would have been in serious financial strife. That Justice Statement money got them out of serious strife. I cannot answer the question: was the money spent for the purposes for which it was allocated? A person can have some reasonable suspicions, but that is on the record of the report.

The administration has been a maverick administration. The Chief Justice of the Family Court is responsible for the administration of the court, but it has been a maverick administration. In what way has it been a maverick administration? They had a review of the court—the Buckley review—and the court went ahead and implemented the Buckley review's recommendations. It did not get the agreement of the Attorney-General's Department or the Department of Finance, but it went ahead and implemented them with no cost-benefit analysis. In fact, the report criticises the fact that cost-benefit analyses seem to be foreign to them. When they did a review of the Buckley review, they put in charge a very esteemed justice—Justice Buckley. He was reviewing his own review!

If I were a member of the government, and I said that we were following the same procedure with CES or DEET, opposition members would be attacking me as an irresponsible administrator. You have to say that the Chief Justice's action is irresponsible. I believe that the committee says that; the committee also says that we have to make a commitment to proactive counselling by getting it out of the Family Court. The court does require counselling. There is no argument about that. But it is a different question as to whether they should be court appointed counsellors.

In the long term we should follow New Zealand, where they have the money and they buy the resources. It works appropriately over there and I think it will work well with the Family Court. But the Family Court has shown—notwithstanding its rhetoric about the importance of court counselling—that it does not manage court counselling. In fact, it does not manage anything with a client focus very well at all.

I remind the chamber of my speech where I referred to the extraordinary amounts of money that people are spending on family law. It is important that we should do a study to see how much money is being spent. We know how much legal aid is being spent and what proportion of that goes on family law, but we have absolutely no idea of what individuals are paying. Until we get an alternative to a litigation superhighway, we are not going to get anywhere.

I proposed a commission of the family. I am disappointed that idea is not being picked up. At its core it provided a choice for people doing it outside the courts and outside legal expense. But I believe the report in funding administration at least sets the foundations for reform. I would be surprised if, in the future, we do not see that eventuate.

I have been publicly critical of judicial productivity. It is interesting that the report calls for more registrars, but not so as increase the overall numbers of judicial officers. Maybe I am remiss in having raised so inelegantly the issue of judicial productivity—but I am vindicated.

To those who were so keen to get behind the unfair attack of the Chief Justice on me, I say that they should read this report in detail. I say that any honourable member should read this report. It is an important report. It does not go so far as I would like, but it sets a platform for reform. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a privilege to have heard the previous speaker, the member for ChifIey (Mr Price). I listened carefully to him. I am not learned in such matters and I have not studied them in such detail, but I know of his great commitment and the effort that was put into the committee he referred to. I commend him for his comments.

PARA.TAB: I want to touch on a similar matter to the one mentioned by the previous speaker. The member for Aston (Mr Nugent) reminded us that we are dealing with people and we have to come to a practical reality of that situation. We know that we have a breakdown in marriages of about two in five, and it is predicted that will go to three in five by the year 2000. Those are figures produced by some learned students on the matter.

The member for Aston and the member for Chifley referred to both the judiciary and the administration of justice. I think that the member for Aston said that it seemed to depend at times upon which judge you may draw in the morning.

I wish to put on the record today a constituent's experience and concern. That is one way I can relate this to the parliament. The name of the gentleman is Malcolm Klinger; he is from a small community called Port Broughton. His marriage ended up in an irretrievable breakdown and he found himself in the Family Court.

I tell this from Malcolm Klinger's perspective. In his advice to me, he explained to me that his wife did not have a deadline to reply to lawyers requesting an alteration on custody. There was a contact agreement—not an access agreement; I learned that from the parliamentary secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) this morning—with his wife. His wife agreed to something and then backed away from it. He felt aggrieved by that.

But he felt particularly aggrieved in the court hearing process itself, when there was a hearing to determine interim custody of the child. Malcolm's submission cost $5,000. His understanding was that the judge was not even able to read it. His wife, of course—after he had spent his $5,000—received legal aid. He felt that that $5,000 was wasted in the Family Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not get a fair go.
—He very much felt that. But let me go on, to touch on some of the points that the member for Chifley was discussing when talking about maintenance for the child.

PARA.TAB: This happened at a time when farm interest rates were 17 per cent. He made the point that the government was able to give his wife a sole parent pension within 24 hours of her leaving him. Then the Child Support Agency asked for an amount which was equivalent to the income he was actually receiving from the farm. He had some other, investment, income, but some of that was from interest.

Eventually—I guess it was not that long; within some months—he was left with the options of working on the farm for nothing, or leaving. So he left the farm in 1992. He now pays no child support, because he is unemployed. In fact, he is on a sickness benefit, but he would otherwise be entitled to unemployment benefit. There is one citizen's experience which, I think, backs up the comments that we have heard about the issues facing our Family Court.

I will finish on one issue. I am going to be very careful, because this issue is sub judice. I guess I prohibit myself from even discussing it, so I will finish that part of the comment. But when I see constituents come to me, and I see the agony, the tears and the complete disillusionment at the loss of a loved one, I, as a member of parliament, am totally at a loss.

I do not say that it is the fault of anyone in particular. All I know is that these people feel totally deserted by our system. There is a great challenge—as I think the comments from previous speakers today indicate—in the administration of our Family Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the contribution made by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), as well as the contribution made by my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin).

PARA.TAB: I have had, for a very long time, major concerns in relation to the operations of the Family Court. I do not wish to reflect on the judiciary, but I must say that, right from the time the Family Court was instituted, while I could fully understand why it was necessary to reform the family law, I was concerned that a special purpose court had been set up for family law matters.

I personally believe that this area of the law ought to have been dealt with in an ordinary court rather than in a court for matrimonial matters. I must say that I have had numerous complaints from people who feel that they have not had a fair go through the Family Court. They emerge from hearings sometimes feeling that they simply have not been listened to. I believe that confidence in our judicial system is absolutely vital and, when we do have a court about which so many complaints are made to honourable members on both sides of the House, it is appropriate for inquiries to take place into the efficiency of that court and the operation of that court to see what reforms are necessary.

Mr Deputy Speaker, that was why I was particularly pleased that perhaps you granted some indulgence to the honourable member for Chifley, because you could see he had put a tremendous amount of effort into that report. You could see that he was greatly aggrieved by the attack made on him by the Chief Justice of the Family Court, and it would be, I believe, a perversion of the standing orders if a member of parliament were not able to have a right of reply. Fortunately the standing orders proved adequate for the honourable member for Chifley to express his point of view. It seems to me that he did have a very considerable amount of extra material which he would have liked to outline to the committee.

I must say I was somewhat tempted to move an extension of time. In the almost six years I have been a member of this place, in two terms and two manifestations, I have never before felt moved to permit a member opposite to have an extension of time, but it was clear that what the honourable member for Chifley was saying needed to be said. I hope that the government looks very closely at the speech made by the honourable member for Chifley, because the family law system is a very important part of our judicial system. As was mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Grey, some 40 per cent of Australians are now affected personally by the tragedy of divorce and 100 per cent of Australians are touched by the tragedy of divorce, because, if not affected personally, they have brothers and sisters and other members of the family and friends who are involved in divorces. It is important that people feel they are able to go to a system where their concerns are able to be addressed and where people are given a fair go by those who administer that particular avenue of the legal system.

This bill we are discussing today is the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. While it is a bill that seeks to amend a large number of other pieces of legislation, this particular bill does not establish new principles. It seeks to build on the reforms of the Family Law Reform Bill 1994, which was broadly supported by the coalition. As a result of the passage of that legislation, it has been necessary, in the view of the government, to make consequential amendments to other acts, including the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, the Child Support Assessment Act 1988, the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988, the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977, the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987, the Marriage Act 1961, the Migration Act 1958, the Passports Act 1938, the Social Security Act 1991 and also the Evidence Act 1995.

When one looks at a number of these changes which the government seeks to implement as a result of the bill we are currently debating, one wonders whether the government has been a little precious in some instances, because the changes are not changes of substance but merely changes of terminology. The principal bill, the Family Law Reform Bill 1994, sought to create a new culture in the area of custody and maintenance. It sought to do away with the idea that parents owned their children. The coalition did not oppose those particular changes but, when one looks at some consequential amendments which are sought to be implemented pursuant to this bill, one wonders if they are really worth the time of this committee.

I do not intend to detain the Main Committee at length by going into the many and varied changes which are being made, but one ought to look at, for instance, item 13 in schedule 1, where we are told that the proposed legislation we are now debating omits `liable parent' and substitutes the same words, but in bold type. One would have thought that, by any means of interpretation of the English language, the words `liable parent' in bold type mean exactly the same as the words `liable parent' in ordinary type. I dare say that those who draft these changes to legislation have to justify their existence, with the result that we are debating such an alteration. One looks at other suggestions where words like `entitled custodian' are replaced by `entitled carer', and so on.

I suppose that, given we are going to create a new culture, it is deemed necessary to modernise the language, but, to be honest, it seems to me to be a little too precious when one looks at the large number of acts which are being changed. The important act is the Family Law Reform Bill 1994, which broadly had the support of both sides of the parliament, but now we are debating consequential changes which are not opposed by us.

Therefore, we join with the government in supporting the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995, although I personally reiterate the concerns expressed by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) in relation to the Family Court system. Obviously the member opposite the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) would also have received very many complaints from his constituents in relation to family law, and it is important that, as parliamentarians, we get this area of the law right. We are dealing with an area of the law which involves human emotion. Many people have broken marriages and children resulting from those marriages. Sadly, so often, people have tended to use children as a means of getting at the other partner to the marriage, and this is tragic.

Although this legislation seeks to enshrine the welfare of the children as being paramount—I think that everyone supports this aim—it is important that the parliament continues to look at reform of family law. This bill and the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 both go some way towards reforming family law, but I hope the government considers the rest of the matters raised by the honourable member for Chifley. Since the Family Law Act has been in place now for close to 20 years, it is incumbent on the government to look at the matters raised by the honourable member for Chifley with some urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am pleased to conclude this debate by saying at the outset that I thank all honourable members who have contributed to the debate. I think it is fair to say that the debate this afternoon is an interesting example of the effective way in which the Main Committee gives members the opportunity to debate in a more measured manner than often occurs in the House of Representatives itself.

PARA.TAB: Many of the comments that were made by honourable members have some validity and most of the contributions were made with the intention of contributing positively to the debate; I certainly took them in this regard. The high point of this debate is clearly the contribution by the member for Chifley (Mr Price). I noted his contribution, and he has raised some issues which bear further consideration. The government will certainly be looking at the points made by the member for Chifley.

I want to reflect briefly on the contributions that some other members made earlier in the debate. It is important that people understand that the new changes that have been made to the Family Law Act in relation to children have quite dramatically changed the direction of the legislation. Instead of talking about the rights of divorcing parties in relation to their children, we are now talking about the rights of the children in these marriages as against the rights of the parents, so, from now on, everything which flows from this legislation will be couched in the context of the rights and interests of the children. This is a very important change—and a quite fundamental one—which has taken place as a result of the passage of the main piece of legislation

I think that we will see, over a period of time, a change in the culture of the Family Court and the application of the law in the area of divorce and marriage breakdown. We will see more concentration on solutions and outcomes and less concentration on the war itself and the battle between the waring parties. And that will be wholly good for the parties themselves and, of course, for their offspring, and will be much better for society at large.

The critical thing that I want to say as my last point in this debate is that we in the parliament can only pass the legislation. It will be up to the Family Court and mediators, and others associated with divorce and marriage breakdown, and the context in which they operate to really determine how effective this legislation will be. We have passed a piece of legislation which has been dealt with extensively and with great consultation and which generally has the overwhelming support of interested parties.
